results.title: Ken Howard: saddler and harness maker
results.brief_description: Provides an insight into the life and work of Ken Howard now one of the few remaining craftsmen in the art of saddlery, who uses traditional methods in preference to new technology.

results.title: Don't think I don't think. Fair enough
results.creator_credit: Dale Baker, Open Channel Productions, La Trobe University, Preston Institute of Technology and Hodja Ed Res Co-op
results.brief_description: 1. “Don’t think I don’t think”. A workshop of the 1981 South Pacific Regional Conference on Mental Retardation. 2. “Fair enough”. The experiences of students finding difficulty in mantaining dignity and rights in the face of “hidden curricula” of school.

results.title: Populations
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Ecology Series”.
Describes most of the principles that cause animal and plant populations to look and behave as they do. Notes the constant change of populations, why this happens and how plants and animals take steps to ensure their survival. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Cricket: Australian style
results.creator_credit: Neil Howe, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A documentary on cricket as it is played in Australia in 1974. Offers highlights from a match between Australia and New Zealand and presents comments about the game by the then Australian captain Ian Chappell.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Neil Howe, Don Murray and Film Australia

results.title: Taxi
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The film shows the daily work of Jim McKenzie, a taxi driver from Perth in Western Australia. Jim lives five miles from the city with his wife and daughter. He owns his own cab and has been in the business for four years. The hours are long - but driving a cab means that a man is his own boss - which is imnportant to Jim McKenzie.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 111
results.brief_description: Magazine items: Susan Knight, ballet student and N.S.W. springboard diving champion; Venetian glassblowing introduced by new citizens; Monowai’s captain recalls forty years of Sydney’s progress. No other credits available.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 097
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The following items are featured in this interesting cinemagazine: a versatile woman runs a farm by herself; blindness poses no impediment to a group of children’s happiness and ship provisioning is a skilled and intricate job.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 089
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: To painters and riggers working on Sydney’s Harbour Bridge walking on narrow girders high above the city is no different to walking down a suburban street; Bell Bay, Tasmania, is the site of the first complete aluminium smelter in the Southern hemisphere; Sydney’s Garrison Church provides a link with early pioneers; Australian Boy Scouts take part in the Eighth World Jamboree held at Niagara, Canada.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Australian diary. No. 088
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A team of women golfers from Britain show their skill on Sydney’s Kensington Links; Trade Unions celebrate the centenary of the movement for shorter working hours - 8 hours work, 8 hours recreation, 8 hours rest; the Valley of Burragorang is deemed to die in the interests of progress - a vast inland sea providing water for Sydney will take possession of the land.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 085
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The following stories are featured in this interesting cinemagazine: for miles along the New South Wales coast oyster growers practice intense cultivation - studying the oysters food requirmentd and encouraging it to breed; members of Sydney’s Miniature Locomotive Society run trains for children and at the same time raise money for charity; Montagu Swamp in North-West Tasmania is cleared to provide land for agriculture.
